facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated May 2, 1961 of Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No.10 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 2, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No.10 of 1954.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed order of District Judge dismissing Execution Application filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the Allahabad High Court companyfirming the order of the District Judge dismissing an Execution Application filed by the appellant.

facts.text: On June 16, 1948 the appellant entered into an agreement with Aziz Ahmed Khan (respondent No.1) for sale of houses and plots in Bareilly for Rs. 1,45,000 already paid.

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1948 the appellant entered into an agreement with Aziz Ahmed Khan--respondent No. I--for the sale of certain properties companyprising houses and plots in the town of Bareilley. The sale companysideration of Rs. 1,45,000/- was stated have been already paid by the appellant to the vendor.

facts.text: Disputes arose between vendor and appellant regarding completion of sale.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently disputes arose between the vendor and the appellant regarding the companypletion of the sale.

facts.text: Disputes referred to arbitration of Shri R.R. Agarwal.

anchor.surface_text: These disputes were refered to the arbitration of Shri R.R. Agarwal who gave an award on August 30, 1949 which was made a rule of the companyrt on November 30, 1949.

facts.text: Arbitrator gave award on August 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: who gave an award on August 30, 1949 which was made a rule of the companyrt on November 30, 1949. A decree on the basis of the award was granted in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Award made rule of court on November 30, 1949; decree granted in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: which was made a rule of the companyrt on November 30, 1949. A decree on the basis of the award was granted in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Aziz Ahmed Khan left India for Pakistan sometime after November 22, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Sometimes after November 22, 1949 the vendor Aziz Ahmed Khan left India for Pakistan.

facts.text: On December 7, 1950 appellant moved Deputy Custodian Judicial Meerut Circle for confirmation of transfer under s.38 of Ordinance 27/1949 or s.40 of Act 31/1950.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1950 the appellant moved the Deputy Custodian  Judicial  Meerut Circle for companyfirmation of the transfer under s. 38 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949,  Ordinance No. 27 of 1949 , or under s. 40 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act 1950  Act 31 of 1950 .

facts.text: On May 9, 1951 Deputy Custodian accorded confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th May 1951 the Deputy Custodian accorded companyfirmation.

facts.text: Additional Custodian took suo motu action and set aside Deputy Custodian's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian, however, took suo motu action in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction and set aside the order passed by the Deputy Custodian.

facts.text: On April 4, 1952 appellant filed application for execution of decree.

anchor.surface_text: On April 4,. 1952 the appellant filed an application for execution of the decree passed on the basis of the award.

facts.text: On May 10, 1952 objections filed on behalf of Custodian to execution.

anchor.surface_text: On May 10, 1952 objections were filed on behalf of the Custodian to the execution.

facts.text: District Judge dismissed execution application holding no transfer effect without approvals, no charge created, s.17(1) bar.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge held that the award made on August 30, 1949 companyld number have the effect of transferring the properties as the approval of the Collector had number been obtained under the numberification dated July 29, 1949 which had been issued under s. 26 of U.P. Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance No. 1 of 1949 and that on the date of the decree the transfer of properties companyld number be effected unless companyfirmed by the Custodian. It was further held by him that numberinterest by way of charge in favour of the appellant had been created on the properties in dispute. He was further of the view that s. 17 1  of the Central Act of 1950 created a bar to execution of the decree.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal to High Court which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal to the High Court which was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on February 22, 1968; questions remitted to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal came up for hearing before this Court on February 22, 1968 it was. companysidered expedient to have further findings on certain points. The following questions were therefore framed and remitted to the High Court for that purpose.

facts.text: District Judge found Aziz Ahmed Khan migrated to Pakistan after November 22, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: His finding on the first question was that Aziz Ahmed Khan had migrated to Pakistan on some date after November 22, 1949.

facts.text: District Judge found properties of Aziz Ahmed Khan did not vest in Custodian under any Ordinances or Central Act 31 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question he found that Aziz Ahmed Khans properties did number vest in the Custodian of Evacuee Property under any of the Ordinances or under the Central Act 31 of 1950.

facts.text: High Court agreed with District Judge's findings on both remitted points.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court expressed agreement with the companyclusions of the District Judge on both the points.

facts.text: District Judge found no valid declaration under s.7(1) of Central Ordinance 27/1949 or corresponding in Act 31/1950 declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that on certain subsidiary points the. learned District Judge had .also found that it had number been proved that a valid declaration under s. 7 1  of the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or of the companyresponding provision in the Central Act 31 of 1950 was made for declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan an evacuee.

facts.text: Additional Custodian declined to confirm the transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Custodian declined to companyfirm the transfer and thus the companydition precedent for the transfer to become effective remained unsatisfied.

facts.text: Award directed Aziz Ahmed Khan to execute documents after obtaining confirmation or approval according to law.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that even in the award which formed the basis of the decree it had been provided the second party  Aziz Ahmed Khan  is hereby directed to execute the necessary documents in respect of the transfer by him of the properties referred to above within one month from the date of the receipt of the companyfirmation or approval according to law failing which the first party will, at his option, get the same executed and registered through companyrt on the basis of this award which would be made a rule of the companyrt.

facts.text: Para 6 of award: claim of Rs. 1,50,000 principal, interest, expenses against Aziz Ahmed Khan at 12% if transaction not confirmed; properties charged; remedies against all properties and person.

anchor.surface_text: Para 6 of the award which became part of the decree was as follows -- The claim of the first party for this transfer and exchange companysideration is Rs. 1,50,000/-  one lac fifty thousand  on account of all principal money and interest and other expenses calculated to date against the second party Sri Aziz Ahmed Khan, which the second party will pay with interest at 12 per cent per annum in case the transaction and transfer of the properties referred to above in favour of the first part Sri Sardana is number companyfirmed or approved in any way and for any other reasons whatsoever. Sri Sardana will force the payments against the properties referred to above. and these properties are hereby charged with this claim and Sri Sardana will have his remedies to enforce the payment of the above claim against all other properties of the second party and also against his person.

facts.text: High Court dealt with para 6 as charge on evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the judgment under appeal dealt with this question as if the charge was on the evacuee property.

facts.text: Aziz Ahmed Khan became an evacuee by leaving India for Pakistan after March 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: One of the meanings of the word evacuee as .given in the definition in s. 2 d  of the Ordinance and of the Act was -- Section 2 d  i  evacuee means any person,-- who, on account of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan or on account of civil disturbances or the fear o.f such disturbances leaves or has, on or after the 1st day of March, 1947, left any place in a Province for any place outside the territories number forming part of India, Aziz Ahmed Khan became an evacuee within the meaning of the above definition.

Ordinance 1 of 1949 or Central Ordinance 12 of 1949 as made applicable to the State of U.P. by U.P. Ordinance 20 of 1949 or under the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or under Central Act of 1950?

anchor.surface_text: 2  whether the properties of Aziz Ahmed Khan vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property under U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 or Central Ordinance 12 of 1949 as made applicable to the State of U.P. by U.P. Ordinance 20 of 1949 or under the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or under

issues.text: Whether a valid declaration under s.7(1) of the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or corresponding provision in Central Act 31 of 1950 was made declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan an evacuee?

anchor.surface_text: that it had number been proved that a valid declaration under s. 7 1  of the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or of the companyresponding provision in the Central Act 31 of 1950 was made for declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan an evacuee.

issues.text: Whether confirmation by the Custodian is required under s.38(1) of Ordinance 27/1949 or s.40(1) of Act 31/1950 for a transfer to be effective if the transferor becomes an evacuee after the transfer?

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a serious hurdle in the way of the appel- lant even when the provisions of Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or the Central Act 31 of 1950 are taken into companysideration. Section 38 1  of that Ordinance provided that numbertransfer of any right or interest in any property after the 14th day of August 1947 by or on behalf of an evacuee or by or on behalf of a person who had become an evacuee after the date of the transfer shall be effective so as to companyfer any rights or remedies on the parties to such transfer unless it was companyfirmed by the Custodian.

issues.text: Whether the executing court can direct execution and registration of a conveyance under the specific performance decree without prior custodian confirmation?

The companyrt companyld and should have executed d companyveyance in favour of the appellant since Aziz Ahmed Khan was numberlonger available or was refusing to do so and the companyfirmation of the Custodian companyld be obtained before the registration was effected.

holdings.text: Transfer of property after 14 August 1947 by a person who becomes an evacuee after the date of transfer is ineffective unless confirmed by the Custodian under s.38(1) of Ordinance 27/1949 and s.40(1) of Act 31/1950, even without prior declaration or notification of the property as evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a serious hurdle in the way of the appel- lant even when the provisions of Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or the Central Act 31 of 1950 are taken into companysideration. Section 38 1  of that Ordinance provided that numbertransfer of any right or interest in any property after the 14th day of August 1947 by or on behalf of an evacuee or by or on behalf of a person who had become an evacuee after the date of the transfer shall be effective so as to companyfer any rights or remedies on the parties to such transfer unless it was companyfirmed by the Custodian.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.38(1) and s.40(1) explicitly covers transfers by persons who become evacuees post-transfer; no requirement for prior vesting or declaration.

holdings.text: Aziz Ahmed Khan became an evacuee under s.2(d) of Ordinance 27/1949 and Act 31/1950 by leaving India for Pakistan after 1 March 1947.

anchor.surface_text: One of the meanings of the word evacuee as .given in the definition in s. 2 d  of the Ordinance and of the Act was -- Section 2 d  i  evacuee means any person,-- who, on account of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan or on account of civil disturbances or the fear o.f such disturbances leaves or has, on or after the 1st day of March, 1947, left any place in a Province for any place outside the territories number forming part of India, Aziz Ahmed Khan became an evacuee within the meaning of the above definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition of 'evacuee' to undisputed fact of migration to Pakistan post-1 March 1947.

holdings.text: Confirmation of transfer by Custodian was necessary and condition precedent not satisfied as Additional Custodian declined to confirm, rendering transfer ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: It was necessary, therefore, for the appellant to have obtained the companyfirmation of the Custodian in respect of the transfer which had been made by Aziz Ahmed Khan in his favour of the properties in question. The Additional Custodian declined to companyfirm the transfer and thus the companydition precedent for the transfer to become effective remained unsatisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.38/40 to facts: evacuee status post-transfer triggers confirmation requirement; administrative refusal leaves transfer invalid.

holdings.text: Executing court cannot execute or register conveyance under the decree without prior Custodian confirmation, as barred by award terms and s.39 Ordinance 27/1949 and s.40 Act 31/1950.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 39 of the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 no document could be registered of the nature mentioned in s. 38 unless the Custodian had confirmed the transfer. Similar provisions were contained in s. 40 of the Central Act 31 of 1950. The prayer in the Execution Application that the court might grant assistance by execution of sale deed under the enabling para 5 of the Decree could not be entertained or acceded to by the Executing Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award conditions execution on prior confirmation; statutory registration bars apply; executing court cannot bypass.

holdings.text: Award requires execution of transfer documents only after obtaining Custodian confirmation or approval according to law.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that even in the award which formed the basis of the decree it had been provided the second party  Aziz Ahmed Khan  is hereby directed to execute the necessary documents in respect of the transfer by him of the properties referred to above within one month from the date of the receipt of the confirmation or approval according to law failing which the first party will, at his option, get the same executed and registered through court on the basis of this award which would be made a rule of the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of award para directing post-confirmation execution.

holdings.text: High Court incorrect to treat para 6 of award as creating charge on evacuee property, given no declaration under Central Ordinance 27/1949 or Act 31/1950; question left open for future proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: There is one matter, however, on which we would like to express our view and leave it open... Para 6 of the award which became part of the decree was as follows -- The claim of the first party... The High Court in the judgment under appeal dealt with this question as if the charge was on the evacuee property. On the reasoning which has been pressed before us about the necessity Of a declaration under the provisions of Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or Central Act 31 of 1950 this part of the judgment does not appear to be correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evacuee declaration per prior findings; expressly refrains from final opinion to allow future adjudication.

holdings.text: Properties of Aziz Ahmed Khan did not vest in Custodian under U.P. Ordinance 1/1949, Central Ordinance 12/1949, U.P. Ordinance 20/1949, Central Ordinance 27/1949, or Central Act 31/1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question he found that Aziz Ahmed Khans properties did not vest in the Custodian of Evacuee Property under any of the Ordinances or under the Central Act 31 of 1950. ... The High Court expressed agreement with the conclusions of the District Judge on both the points.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of lower courts' findings on remitted issue; no automatic vesting applicable post-migration date.

holdings.text: No valid declaration under s.7(1) Central Ordinance 27/1949 or corresponding provision in Act 31/1950 declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan evacuee or properties evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that on certain subsidiary points the. learned District Judge had .also found that it had not been proved that a valid declaration under s. 7 1  of the Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or of the corresponding provision in the Central Act 31 of 1950 was made for declaring Aziz Ahmed Khan an evacuee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of lower court finding on subsidiary remitted point; necessary for vesting but irrelevant for s.38/40.

precedents.citation: Azimunissa Others v. The Deputy Custodian Evacuee Properties, District Deoria Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: Azimunissa Others v. The Deputy Custodian Evacuee Properties, District Deoria Ors.  1  in which the effect of the declaration of U.P. Ordinance l of 1949 to be invalid by the companyrts came up for the companysideration, as also of the subsequent evacuee legislation namely, Central Ordinance 27 of 1949, Central Act 31 of 1950 and the Administration of Evacuee Property  Amendment  Act, 1960. It appears to have been held in that case that the property which had vested under the U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 companytinued to vest in the Custodian numberwithstanding the ,fact that the High Court of Allahabad in Azimunnissa Ors. v. Assistant Custodian 2  held the vesting to be invalid.

precedents.case_name: Azimunissa v. Deputy Custodian Evacuee Properties
precedents.cited_proposition: Property vested under U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 continued to vest in the Custodian notwithstanding High Court holding the vesting invalid, due to s. 8(2-A) introduced by Amendment Act 1 of 1960
precedents.cited_holding: vesting under U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 continued despite invalidity

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Allahabad in Azimunnissa Ors. v. Assistant Custodian 2  held the vesting to be invalid. This was the result of the introduction of s. 8 2-A  in the Central Act of 1931 by the Central Amendment Act I of 960.

precedents.cited_proposition: Vesting of property under U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 was invalid
precedents.cited_holding: vesting under U.P. Ordinance 1 of 1949 invalid

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a serious hurdle in the way of the appel- lant even when the provisions of Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or the Central Act 31 of 1950 are taken into companysideration. Section 38 1  of that Ordinance provided that numbertransfer of any right or interest in any property after the 14th day of August 1947 by or on behalf of an evacuee or by or on behalf of a person who had become an evacuee after the date of the transfer shall be effective so as to companyfer any rights or remedies on the parties to such transfer unless it was companyfirmed by the Custodian.

The prayer in the Execution Application that the companyrt might grant assistance by execution of sale deed under the enabling para 5 of the Decree companyld number be entertained or acceded to by the Executing Court.

anchor.surface_text: It was necessary, therefore, for the appellant to have obtained the companyfirmation of the Custodian in respect of the transfer which had been made by Aziz Ahmed Khan in his favour of the properties in question. The Additional Custodian declined to companyfirm the transfer and thus the companydition precedent for the transfer to become effective remained unsatisfied.

The prayer in the Execution Application that the companyrt might grant assistance by execution of sale deed under the enabling para 5 of the Decree companyld number be entertained or acceded to by the Executing Court.

Similar provisions were contained in s. 40 of the Central Act 31 of 1950. anchor.surface_text: There is one matter, however, on which we would like to express our view and leave it open... Para 6 of the award which became part of the decree was as follows -- The claim of the first party... The High Court in the judgment under appeal dealt with this question as if the charge was on the evacuee property. On the reasoning which has been pressed before us about the necessity Of a declaration under the provisions of Central Ordinance 27 of 1949 or Central Act 31 of 1950 this part of the judgment does not appear to be correct.
